question.text: The domain of definition of the function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi> </mi><msqrt><msub><mi>log</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mfenced><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfenced></msqrt></math>, is

solution.text:
log x-1⁡ x2+4x+4≥0

Case 1: 0<x-1<1

i.e., 1<x<2 , then
0<x2+4x+4 ≤1 ⇒    x2+4x+3 ≤0 & x+22>0

⇒ -3 ≤x ≤-1 & x≠-2

So, x∈-2, -1

Case 2: x-1>1

i.e., x>2

x2+4x+4 ≥1⇒x+1x+3≥0⇒x∈ -∞,-3  ∪ -1 ,∞

⇒ x∈-∞, -3∪2, ∞
 
Hence, domain is -∞,-3 ∪(-2,-1)∪2,∞

question.text: If domain of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>[</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo><mo>,</mo></math> then find the domain of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mrow><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math>

solution.text:
1≤log2x2+3x-2≤3⇒2≤x2+3x-2≤8
On solving them, we get -5≤x≤-4 and 1≤x≤2

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><msqrt><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi></msqrt><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><msqrt><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></msqrt></math>, then

options.text: range of <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> has two elements only
<math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> contains only two elements in its domain

solution.text:
∵ x2+4x≥0 for the first term

and 0≤x2+4x+1≤1 for the second term

∴ by both the results, there is only one possibility

x2+4x=0

⇒x=0,-4

∴ fx=tan-10+sin-11=π2 

Hence, fx contains only two elements in its domain

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfenced></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></math> (where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mo>.</mo></mfenced></math> represents the greatest integer part of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>), then the range of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> is

solution.text:
x2-x2=x2

∴ fx=x21+x2=1+x2-11+x2=1-11+x2

∵ 0≤x2<1⇒1≤x2+1<2

12<1x2+1≤1⇒-12>-11+x2≥-1

12>1+-11+x2≥0⇒ Range of fx∈0,12

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>sin</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>cos</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>sin</mi><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math> then the range of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is

solution.text:
Let f(x)=sin4x-sinxcosx+cos4x
f(x)=1-12sin2x-12sin22x
⇒f(x)=g(t)=1-12t-12t2  t∈[-1,1]
Hence f(x)∈0,98

question.text: Domain and range of the function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msqrt><msup><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></msqrt></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced open="[" close="]"><mrow><mfrac><mi>a</mi><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt></mfrac><mo>,</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>[</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>d</mi><msqrt><mn>5</mn><mi>π</mi></msqrt><mo>]</mo></math>  respectively, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>d</mi></math> is equal to

solution.text:
\(\sin ^{-1}(3 x)+\frac{\pi}{3} \geqslant 0\) and \(3 x \in[-1,1]\)
\(\sin ^{-1}(3 x) \geqslant-\frac{\pi}{3}\)
\(1 \geqslant 3 x \geqslant-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\)
\(\frac{1}{3} \geqslant x \geqslant \frac{-\sqrt{3}}{6}\)
domain is \(\left[\frac{-1}{2 \sqrt{3}}, \frac{1}{3}\right] \quad \therefore a=\frac{-1}{2} ~\&~ b=1\).
For Range put \(x=\frac{-1}{2 \sqrt{3}}\) and \(x=\frac{1}{3}\)
at \(x=\frac{-1}{2 \sqrt{3}} \quad b\left(\frac{-1}{2 \sqrt{3}}\right)=0\)
at \(x=\frac{1}{3} \quad b\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) = \sqrt{\frac{5 \pi}{6}}\)
So \(C=0\) and \(d=\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}}\)
\(2 a+b+c+6 d=\sqrt{6}\)

question.text: The number of integral value(s) of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> which satisfying the equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="|" open="|"><mrow><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced></math><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></math><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="|" open="|"><mrow><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="|" open="|"><mrow><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math>

solution.text:
Since a+b=a+b⇒ab≥0

So, log42x2-x≥0⇒2x2-x≥1

⇒(2x+1)(x-1)≥0⇒x≤-12 or x≥1

and log22-x2≥0⇒2-x2≥1

⇒x2≤1⇒-1≤x≤1

Hence, x∈-1, -12∪1

i.e. 2 integral values.

question.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>[</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>]</mo></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>{</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>}</mo></math> represent the greatest integer function and fractional part function respectively. Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>[</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>]</mo><mo>+</mo><munderover><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>2020</mn></munderover><mfrac><mrow><mo>{</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>}</mo></mrow><mn>2020</mn></mfrac><mo>.</mo></math> Find the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1000</mn><mo>)</mo></math>

solution.text:
f(x)=[x]+∑r=12020{x+r}2020

=[x]+∑r=12020{x}+r2020
=[x]+20202020{x}+1+2+3+…+20202020
=[x]+{x}+2020×20212×2020
=x+20212

question.text: The function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mn>(</mn><mi>x</mi><mn>)</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>sec</mi><mfenced close="]" open="["><mrow><mi>log</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>+</mo><msqrt><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></msqrt></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math> is

options.text: neither an odd nor an even function

solution.text:
f −x =sec log −x+ 1+ x 2    

=sec⁡log⁡x+ 1+x2-1  

 ∵1+x2-x= 11+x2+x

=sec −log x+ 1+ x 2    

=seclog x+1+x2     ∵sec−θ=secθ 

=f(x)

Hence f(x) is an even function.

question.text: Which of the following is a function whose graph is symmetrical about the origin?

solution.text:
A function whose graph is symmetrical about the origin must be odd.
2x+2-x is an even function.
Since, log⁡x+1+x2 is an odd function,
∴log⁡x+1+x22 is an even function.
If fx+y=fx+fy∀x,y∈R, then
Put x=y=0⇒f0=0
Now, put y=-x⇒fx+f-x=0
∴fx is an odd function

question.text: If the graph of the function <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math> is symmetric about the line <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, then the value of <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math> is equal to

solution.text:
fx is symmetric about the line x=2
∴f2+x=f2-x
a2+x3+2+x2+b2+x+c=a2-x3+2-x2+b2-x+c
a2+x3-2-x3+2+x2-2-x2+b2+x-2-x=0
a8+12x+6x2+x3-8-12x+6x2-x3+24x+b2x=0
a24x+2x3+8x+2bx=0
2ax3+24a+2b+8x=0
Which must be true ∀x∈R
∴ it is an identity
∴2a=0, 24a+2b+8=0
a=0, 2b+8=0
b=-4

question.text: The fundamental period of the function <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">sin </mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mo>|</mo><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">cos </mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>|</mo></math> is

solution.text:
fπ2+x=sinπ2+x+cosπ2+x

              = cos  x⁡ + sin  x⁡   for all  x⁡ .

Hence,  f⁡ x⁡   is periodic with period π 2 .

question.text: A function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is defined as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mfenced><mrow><mfrac><mfenced close="|" open="|"><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mfenced close="|" open="|"><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mfrac></mrow></mfenced><mo>.</mo></math> If the fundamental period of function<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo> </mo><mi>f</mi></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi><mi>π</mi></math>, then the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi></math> is

solution.text:
fx=12sinxcosx+sinxcosx

=12sinxcosx+sinxcosx, 0≤x<π2

=12sinxcosx-sinxcosx, π2≤x<π

=12-sinxcosx-sinxcosx, π≤x<3π2

=12-sinxcosx+sinxcosx, 3π2≤x<2π

⇒fx=tanx,  0≤x<π2

=0 , π2≤x<π

=-tanx, π≤x<3π2

=0, 3π2≤x<2π

⇒f is periodic with fundamental period 2π⇒m=2

question.text: If <math><mi>f</mi><mo>:</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>A</mi></math> defined as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mfenced separators="|"><msqrt><mn>4</mn><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced></msqrt></mfenced></math> is surjective, then <math><mi>A</mi></math> is equal to

solution.text:
∵ x2+x+1=x+122+34

∴ 4x2+x+1≥3

⇒4x2+x+1≥3

⇒tan-14x2+x+1≥tan-1(3)

⇒f(x)≥π3
∴ Range of fx is π3,π2

question.text: Which of the following function is surjective but not injective?

solution.text:
fx=x4+2x3-x2+1 is polynomial of even degree hence its range can't be R. Hence not surjective.

fx=x3+x+1, f'x=3x2+1⇒ monotonic hence bijective.

fx=1+x2, neither surjective not injective

fx=x3+2x2-x+1, f'x=3x2+4x-1⇒D=16+12>0

Hence fx is non-monotonic cubic polynomial hence surjective but not injective.

question.text: If <math><mi>f</mi><mo>:</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>R</mi></math> be defined as <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>,</mo></math> then

options.text: <math><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><msqrt><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></msqrt></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math>

<math><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><msqrt><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></msqrt></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math>

solution.text:
Let us check for invertibility of fx
A one-one: we have, fx=e2x-e-2x2
⇒ f ′ x = e 4x +1 e 2x , which is strictly increasing as e4x>0 for all x.
Thus, f is one-one
B Onto: Let y=fx
⇒dydx=e2x+e-2x, where y is strictly monotonic
Hence, the range of fx=f-∞,f∞
⇒ range of fx=-∞,∞
So, the range of fx= co-domain
Hence, fx is one-one and onto
C To find f-1:y=e4x-12e2x
⇒e4x-2e2xy-1=0
⇒e2x=2y±4y2+42
⇒2x=logy±y2+1
⇒f-1y=logy±y2+12
Since, ef-1x is always positive, so neglecting negative sign.
Hence, f-1x=logx+x2+12

question.text: If <math><mi>f</mi><mo>:</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>R</mi></math> be a function such that <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">sin</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></math> Then, the function <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is

solution.text:
fx=x3+x2+4x+sin⁡x

⇒f'x=3x2+2x+4+cos⁡x

f'x=3x+132+119--cos⁡x>0 as 3 x+132+119min=113

and -cos⁡x has the maximum value 1.

⇒fx is strictly increasing and hence it is one-one

Also, limx→∞fx⇒∞ and limx→-∞fx⇒-∞.

Thus, the range of fx is R, hence it is onto.

question.text:
Let f:R→R be a function defined by
fx=x+1x,x>0ex,x≤0 then f is

A function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>:</mo><mo> </mo><mi>Z</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>Z</mi></math> is defined as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>n</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="" open="{"><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" columnspacing="1.4ex"><mtr><mtd><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mi>n</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>odd</mi><mo> </mo><mi>integer</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mfrac><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mtd><mtd><mi>n</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>even</mi><mo> </mo><mi>integer</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>.</mo></mrow></mfenced></math> If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>odd</mi><mo> </mo><mi>integer</mi></math> and <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>33</mn><mo>,</mo></math> then the sum of the digits of <math><mi>k</mi></math> is

solution.text:
∵ k∈odd integer

fk=k+1 which is even

∴ffk=k+12

If k+12 is odd ⇒33=k+12+1⇒k=63 not possible (because k+12 is even)

If k+12 is even ⇒33=k+122⇒33=k+14⇒k=131

Sum of digits =5

question.text: If <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mfenced close="}" open="{" separators="|"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mi> </mi><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfenced></math> and <math><mi>f</mi><mi> </mi><mo>:</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>A</mi></math>, the total number of invertible functions, ‘f’, such that <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>≠</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>≠</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> is equal to

solution.text:
If f2=3⇒f4=2, f3=2

If f2=4 ⇒f4=2 , f3=3

             or

      f4=3, f3=2

Hence there are 3 such functions

question.text: Given two real sets A=a,a2,a3⋯a2n and Bb1,b2,⋯bn. If f:A→B is a function such that every element of B has an inverse image and fa1≤fa2≤fa3≤fa4⋯≤fa2n, then the number of such mappings are

solution.text:
There is no loss of generality in considering the order of bi's as b1<b2<b3⋯<bn also given
that fa1≤fa2·fa2n. Now suppose number of preimages of every bi are xi in numbers. Therefore x1+x2+⋯+xn=2n where 1≤xi≤n+1→(1)
Number of solutions of (1) is Cn-12n-1 or Cn2n-1

question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>{</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>7</mn><mo>}</mo><mo>.</mo></math> Then the number of bijective functions <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>:</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>A</mi></math> such that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math> is equal to

solution.text:
Given the set A={0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7}.

And, also a function f:A→A satisfying f(1)+f(2)=3-f(3)

⇒ f(1)+f(2)+f(3)=3

Since, the range of the function is also A, hence the only possibility satisfying the given condition is: 0+1+2=3

We know that, the number of arrangements of n objects at n places is n!.

Since, the given function is bijective i.e. one-one and onto, hence, the elements 1, 2, 3 in the domain can be mapped with only 0, 1, 2 in the co-domain in 3! ways and the remaining 5 elements 0, 4, 5, 6, 7 in the domain can be mapped with any of the remaining 5 elements 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 in 5! ways. 

So, the number of bijective functions are =3!×5!=6×120=720.

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>:</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mfenced><mrow><mfenced open="[" close="]"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mi>π</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msqrt><mi>x</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo mathvariant="italic">-</mo><mn mathvariant="italic">1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></msqrt></math> ( where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="]" open="["><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> denotes greatest integral value less than or equal to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>) denotes a function, then number of real solutions of equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> is

solution.text:
fx=2x-1+x-12

=x-12x<123x-32x≥12

As fx is increasing, solution of equation fx=f-1x is same as fx=x.

∴ No. of solutions of fx=f-1x is one.

question.text: Equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced open="|" close="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced open="|" close="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn></math> has

solution.text:
We have,

x+4+x-4=-2xx<-48-4≤x≤42xx>4

 

It is clear from the above straight line y=ax+8 cuts the curve y=x+4+x-4 at exactly one point of a∈(-∞,-2]∪[2,∞) exactly two points of a∈-2,0∪0,2 more than two points if a=0. Hence, option C is correct.

question.text: The total number of solution(s) of the equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>tan</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mfenced open="[" close="]" separators="|"><mrow><mn>0,2</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is/are equal to

solution.text:
2x+3tanx=5π2⇒tanx=-23x+5π6
y=tanx and y=5π6-2x3

Both the graphs meet exactly three times in 0,2π.
Thus, there are 3 solutions.

question.text: If <math> <mrow> <mn>2</mn><mtext>f</mtext><mfenced> <mrow> <mtext>xy</mtext></mrow> </mfenced><mo>=</mo><msup> <mrow> <mfenced> <mrow> <mtext>f</mtext><mfenced> <mtext>x</mtext> </mfenced></mrow> </mfenced></mrow> <mtext>y</mtext> </msup> <mo>+</mo><msup> <mrow> <mfenced> <mrow> <mtext>f</mtext><mfenced> <mtext>y</mtext> </mfenced></mrow> </mfenced></mrow> <mtext>x</mtext> </msup> </mrow> </math> for all <math> <mrow> <mtext>x,</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>y</mtext><mo>∈</mo><mtext>R</mtext></mrow> </math> and <math> <mrow> <mtext>f</mtext><mfenced> <mn>1</mn> </mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo></mrow> </math> then the value of <math> <mrow> <munderover> <mi>Σ</mi> <mrow> <mtext>r</mtext> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> </munderover> <mtext>f</mtext> <mfenced close=")" open="(" separators=","> <mrow> <mtext>r</mtext> </mrow> </mfenced> </mrow> </math> is equal to

solution.text:
From given functional equation,  2f xy = f x y + f y x , ∀x, y∈R

putting y=1 ,

2f x =f x + f 1 x

f x = 3 x

∴     Σ r = 1 1 0 f r = Σ r = 1 1 0 3 r = 3 3 1 0 - 1 3 - 1 = 3 2 3 1 0 - 1

question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> be a function such that <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac></math> where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>-</mo><mfenced close="}" open="{"><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced></math>, then the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math> must be

solution.text:

Again, replacing x by 1-1x and solve

question.text: Let <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> be a function defined as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>:</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>R</mi></math> such that <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>–</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> and <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> then the value of the expression <math><mrow><munderover><mo stretchy="false">∑</mo><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>15</mn></mrow></munderover><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>r</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mrow></math> is equal to

solution.text:
∵fx+2+fx–2=fx ...(i)

Replace x by x+2 :fx+4+fx=fx+2 ...(ii)

from eq (i) and (ii) : fx –2+fx+4=0

Replace x by x+2 :fx+fx+6=0 ...(iii)

Replace x by x-2 in eq (i): fx+f(x –4)=fx –2 ...(iv)

from eq (i) and eq (iv): fx+2+fx –4=0

Replace x by x –2 :fx+fx –6=0 ...(v)

from (iii) and (v) : fx+6=fx –6

∴ fx is periodic with period 12.

∴∑r=015f1+12r=f1+f13+f25+.....

=16×f1

=16×3

=48

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>y</mi></mfenced><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>∀</mo><mo> </mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>y</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mn>1</mn></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, then the number of solutions of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>n</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>n</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>N</mi></math>, is

solution.text:
Given,  fx+y=fx+fy-xy-1,∀ x, y∈R

∴ fx+1=fx+f1-x-1 [putting y=1]

⇒fx+1=fx-x  ∵ f1=1

∴ fn+1=fn-n<fn

⇒fn+1<fn

So, fn<fn-1<fn-2<…<f3<f2<f1=1

∴ fn=n holds only for n=1

question.text: If <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is a real valued function such that <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>-</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>0, </mn><mo>∀</mo></math><math><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi></math>, then period of <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is

solution.text:
In given equation, putting x→x+3
fx+9-fx+6+fx+3=0
On adding both equations, we get,
fx+9+fx=0 …(i)
now, putting x→x+9
fx+18+fx+9=0 …(ii)
Equation (ii) – Equation (i)
fx+18=fx
∴Period =18
